section_path: Self-similar Laplacians and almost Mathieu operators / Self-similar $p$ Laplacians on the half-integer lattice
text: \end{aligned}$$ Note that by Proposition 9(4), we conclude that all the $3^l-3^n$ preimages are not in the exceptional set and therefore eigenvalues of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(l)}$, see . Besides, this implies that all the $3^l-3^n$ preimages are distinct eigenvalues. 2. $R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n} ,0} \Big( \sigma(\Delta^{(0)}) \Big)$: By Proposition 9(4), we have $$R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 } \big( \sigma(\Delta^{(0)}) \big)=\sigma \big(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(n)}\big) \bigcup \sigma \big(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(n),D} \big),$$ By excluding the exceptional points, we see that $R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 } \big( \sigma(\Delta^{(0)}) \big)$ generates $3^n+1$ distinct eigenvalues of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(l)}$, namely the eigenvalues in $\sigma \big(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(n)}\big)$. We generated in part one and two $3^l-3^n + 3^n+1 = 3^l+1$ distinct eigenvalues, which shows with a dimension argument that we completely determined the spectrum $\sigma \Big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(l)} \Big)$. ◻

heading.title: Self-similar $p$ Laplacians on the half-integer lattice

section_path: Self-similar Laplacians and almost Mathieu operators / Infinite graphs case
text:
## Infinite graphs case We extend the statement of Theorem 4 to infinite graphs. We provide a complete description of the spectrum of the almost Mathieu operators $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ by relating it to the self-similar Laplacian’s spectrum $\sigma(\Delta_{p})$. The following theorem is the main result.
**Theorem 11**. *Let $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \alpha, \theta}$ and $\Delta_p$ be given as in ([eq:AMOversionPQ]) and ([pLaplace]). Let $p\in (0,1)$, $\beta \in \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{R}}}$ and $n \geq 1$ be fixed. We set $\theta =0$, $\alpha = \frac{k}{3^n}$, for $k \in \{1,\dots, 3^n-1\}$. There exists a polynomial $R_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }$ of order $3^n$ such that,* *$$\sigma \Big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 } \Big) = R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 } \Big( \sigma(\Delta_p) \Big).$$ Moreover, $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ has purely singularly continuous spectrum if $p\neq \frac{1}{2}$.*

section_path: Self-similar Laplacians and almost Mathieu operators / Infinite graphs case
text: *Proof.* The first part of theorem 11 is a consequence of . We proceed as in the previous section and apply the spectral decimation method. We set $\mathcal{H} = \ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ and $\mathcal{H}_0 = \ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$, $n \geq 1$. Strictly speaking, the self-similar Laplacian $\Delta_p$ in Theorem 11 is defined on $\ell^2(3^n\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$. To understand this, we follow and introduce a dilation operator $$D: \ell^2(3^n\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)\to \ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi), \quad \quad (Df)(x)=f(3^n x),$$ and its co-isometric adjoint $$D^{\ast}: \ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi) \to \ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi), \quad \quad (D^{\ast}f)(3^n x)=f(x).$$ Next, we define the operator $\tilde{\Delta}_p$ on $\ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ to be $\tilde{\Delta}_p = D^{\ast}\Delta_p D$. According to , $\tilde{\Delta}_p$ on $\ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ is isometrically equivalent to $\Delta_p$ on $\ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ and $\sigma(\tilde{\Delta}_p)=\sigma(\Delta_p)$. In the following, we will omit the tilde and refer to $\tilde{\Delta}_p$ by $\Delta_p$. We regard $\mathcal{H}_0 = \ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ as a subspace of $\ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ and introduce $\mathcal{H}_1$ as the orthogonal complement of $\mathcal{H}_0$ in $\mathcal{H}$. Then $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ is decomposed with respect to $\mathcal{H}_0\oplus \mathcal{H}_1$ into the following block form $$\label{eq:lDecompoInf} \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p, \beta, \alpha, \theta}=\begin{pmatrix} T & J^T\\ J & X \end{pmatrix}.$$ We observe that $T$ is a multiple of the identity and that $X$ is a block diagonal semi-finite matrix in which the diagonal blocks are the $n$th level Dirichlet almost Mathieu Operator $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(n),D}$, i.e.

section_path: Self-similar Laplacians and almost Mathieu operators / Infinite graphs case
text:
*Proof.* The first part of theorem 11 is a consequence of . We proceed as in the previous section and apply the spectral decimation method. We set $\mathcal{H} = \ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ and $\mathcal{H}_0 = \ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$, $n \geq 1$. Strictly speaking, the self-similar Laplacian $\Delta_p$ in Theorem 11 is defined on $\ell^2(3^n\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$. To understand this, we follow and introduce a dilation operator $$D: \ell^2(3^n\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)\to \ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi), \quad \quad (Df)(x)=f(3^n x),$$ and its co-isometric adjoint $$D^{\ast}: \ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi) \to \ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi), \quad \quad (D^{\ast}f)(3^n x)=f(x).$$ Next, we define the operator $\tilde{\Delta}_p$ on $\ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ to be $\tilde{\Delta}_p = D^{\ast}\Delta_p D$. According to , $\tilde{\Delta}_p$ on $\ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ is isometrically equivalent to $\Delta_p$ on $\ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ and $\sigma(\tilde{\Delta}_p)=\sigma(\Delta_p)$. In the following, we will omit the tilde and refer to $\tilde{\Delta}_p$ by $\Delta_p$. We regard $\mathcal{H}_0 = \ell^2(3^n \mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ as a subspace of $\ell^2(\mathop{\mathrm{{\mathbb{Z}}}}_{+}, d \pi)$ and introduce $\mathcal{H}_1$ as the orthogonal complement of $\mathcal{H}_0$ in $\mathcal{H}$. Then $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ is decomposed with respect to $\mathcal{H}_0\oplus \mathcal{H}_1$ into the following block form $$\label{eq:lDecompoInf} \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p, \beta, \alpha, \theta}=\begin{pmatrix} T & J^T\\ J & X \end{pmatrix}.$$ We observe that $T$ is a multiple of the identity and that $X$ is a block diagonal semi-finite matrix in which the diagonal blocks are the $n$th level Dirichlet almost Mathieu Operator $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(n),D}$, i.e. $$\label{eq: decompoMatricesInf} T = \beta \left(\begin{matrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & \dots \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & \dots \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & \ddots \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots \end{matrix}\right), \quad \quad X = \renewcommand*{\arraystretch}{1.4} \left( \begin{array}{@{}cc@{}c@{}} \ \mbox{\normalfont\Large\bfseries $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n} , 0 }^{(n), D}$} & & \\ % & \mbox{\normalfont\Large\bfseries $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n} , 0 }^{(n), D}$}& \\ % & & \ \mbox{\normalfont\Large\bfseries $\ddots$}\ \text{ } \end{array} \right).$$ Similar to the proof of Lemma 7, the spectral similarity of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n} , 0 }^{(n)}$ and $\Delta^{(0)}$ implies the spectral similarity of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ and $\Delta_p$ with the same $\phi_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0}$, $\psi_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }$, $\mathscr{E}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0}$ and $R_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }$. By , we see that for $z \notin \mathscr{E}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0}$, $$\begin{aligned} z \in \sigma\Big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 } \Big) \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad R_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }(z) \in \sigma(\Delta_p) \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \quad z \in R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 } \big( \sigma(\Delta_p) \big). \end{aligned}$$ Next, we show $\mathscr{E}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0} \subset \sigma\big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 } \big)$. To this end we use Proposition 9 (4), that is $\mathscr{E}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0} \subset R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 } (0,2)$ and the fact that $0$ and $2$ are not isolated points in the spectrum $\sigma(\Delta_p)$. Let $z \in \mathscr{E}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0} \cap R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n} ,0} (0)$. By a continuity argument, we can find a sequence $\{\lambda_m\}_{m \in \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{N}}}} \subset \sigma(\Delta_p)$, $0 < \lambda_m <2$, $\lambda_m \to 0$ and a partial inverse of $R_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n} ,0}$ (which we will denote by $R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n} ,0}$ to avoid extra notation), such that $R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }(\lambda_m) \to z$. Again with proposition 9(4) we have $R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }(\lambda_m) \notin \mathscr{E}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0}$ for all $m \in \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{N}}}$ and imply by that $$R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n} ,0}(\lambda_m) \in \sigma\Big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 } \Big) \quad \forall \ m \in \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{N}}}.$$ By closedness of the spectrum, we conclude that $z \in \sigma\Big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 } \Big)$, see also Remark 14. The same argument holds for $z \in \mathscr{E}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0} \cap R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 } (2)$. The second part of the statement followes by combined with . ◻ # Integrated density of states Throughout this section, we assume that $p\in (0,1)$ and $l \geq 1$ are fixed. We follow ideas presented in and define the *density of states* of $\Delta_{p}$. We start by considering the spectrum of $\Delta^{(l)}_{p}$, which consists of finitely many simple eigenvalues. We refer to the normalized sum of Dirac measures concentrated on the eigenvalues $$% \nu_{l,p}(\{x\}) = \frac1{3^{l} +1} \sum_{\lambda\in \sigma(\Delta^{(l)}_{p})} \delta_\lambda(x)$$ as the *density of states* of $\Delta^{(l)}_{p}$. The *normalized eigenvalue counting* function of $\Delta^{(l)}_{p}$ is then given by $N^{(l)}_{p}(x):=\nu_{l,p}((-\infty,x])$. We note that $\Delta^{(l)}_{p}$ is the restriction of $\Delta_{p}$ to the finite graph $G_{l}=(V_{l}, E_{l})$ while imposing Neumann boundary conditions. As the following results can be derived in the same way when Dirichlet boundary conditions are applied, we restrict our consideration to the former one. Figure [fig:IDSforLaps] depicts the normalized eigenvalue counting function $N^{(l)}_{p}$ for different parameters. We recall some known facts about the spectrum of the self-similar Laplacian $\Delta_{p}$. Theorem 1 and Proposition 10 in show that the spectrum $\sigma(\Delta_{p})$ is the Julia set $\mathcal{J}(R_{\Delta_{p}})$ of the polynomial $R_{\Delta_{p}}$ given in Proposition 6, for more general settings see . For $p=\frac{1}{2}$, we have $\mathcal{J}(R_{\Delta_{\frac{1}{2}}})=[0,2]$ and the spectrum is absolutely continuous. For $p \neq \frac{1}{2}$, the Julia set $\mathcal{J}(R_{\Delta_{p}})$ is a Cantor set of Lebesgue measure zero and the spectrum is purely singularly continuous. Brolin in proved the existence of a natural measure on polynomial Julia sets, namely the so-called balanced invariant measure. Moreover, he showed that the balanced invariant measure coincides with the potential theory’s equilibrium (harmonic) measure. In higher generality the uniqueness of the balanced invariant measure was established later in , the reader is referred to for an overview. Denoting the balanced invariant measure of the Julia set $\mathcal{J}(R_{\Delta_{p}})$ by $\nu_p$ and and using ideas similar to Brolin’s lead to the following result.
**Proposition 12**. *The sequence of density of states $\{\nu_{l,p}\}_{l \in \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{N}}}}$ converges weakly to the balanced invariant measure $\nu_p$ of the Julia set $\mathcal{J}(R_{\Delta_{p}})$.*
Let $\theta =0$, $\beta \in \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{R}}}$, $1 \leq n \leq l$ and $k \in \{0,\dots, 3^n-1\}$ be fixed. In the same way as above, we define the density of states and the normalized eigenvalue counting function of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(l)}$ and refer to them by $\nu^{(l)}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ and $N^{(l)}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$, respectively. Theorem 4 asserts the existence of a polynomial $R_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }$ of order $3^n$. Let $S_1,S_2, \dots, S_{3^n}$ be the $3^n$ branches of the inverse $R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }$ and $E \subset \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{R}}}$ ($\nu_{p}$-measurable). We define the following measure $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:DefNuForAMO} \nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }(E) :=\frac{1 }{3^{n} } \sum_{i=1}^{3^n} \int_{\sigma(\Delta_{p})} \chi_E(S_i(x)) \nu_{p}(dx) \end{aligned}$$ where $\chi_E$ is the characteristic function of the set $E$, i.e. $$\chi_E(x) = \begin{cases} \ 0 & \quad \text{if } x \notin E \\ \ 1 & \quad \text{if } x \in E \end{cases}$$
**Theorem 13**. *Let $\text{supp}(\nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 })$ denotes the support of $\nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$. Then $\text{supp}(\nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 })=\sigma\big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 } \big)$. The sequence of density of states $\big\{\nu^{(l)}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 } \big\}_{l \in \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{N}}}}$ converges weakly to $\nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$. Moreover, the following identity holds $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:almostSelfSimiId} \int_{\sigma( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 } )} f(x) \nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }(dx)=\frac{1 }{3^{n} } \sum_{i=1}^{3^n} \int_{\sigma(\Delta_{p})} f(S_i(x)) \nu_{p}(dx) \end{aligned}$$ for $f \in C_b(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{C}}})$, i.e. $f$ is a continuous bounded function on $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{C}}}$.*
*Proof.* Let $f \in C_b(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{C}}})$. Theorem 4 implies $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:discIntAMOmeasure} \sum_{x \in \sigma( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(l)}) } f(x) \nu^{(l)}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }(\{x\}) = \frac{1}{3^l +1} \sum_{x \in R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 } ( \sigma(\Delta^{(l-n)}_{p}) \backslash \sigma(\Delta^{(0)}) ) } f(x) + \frac{1}{3^l +1} \sum_{x \in \sigma( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }^{(n)}) } f(x). \end{aligned}$$ We show that the first term on the right-hand side of equation ([eq:discIntAMOmeasure]) converges to the term on the right-hand side of equation ([eq:almostSelfSimiId]). $$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{3^l +1} \sum_{x \in R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 } ( \sigma(\Delta^{(l-n)}_{p}) \backslash \sigma(\Delta^{(0)}) ) } f(x) & = \frac{1}{3^l +1} \sum_{x \in \sigma(\Delta^{(l-n)}_{p}) \backslash \sigma(\Delta^{(0)}) } \sum_{i=1}^{3^n} f(S_i(x)) \\ & = \frac{3^{l-n} +1}{3^l +1} \sum_{x \in \sigma(\Delta^{(l-n)}_{p}) \backslash \sigma(\Delta^{(0)}) } \sum_{i=1}^{3^n} f(S_i(x)) \nu_{l-n,p}(\{x\}) \\ & \to \frac{1 }{3^{n} } \sum_{i=1}^{3^n} \int_{\sigma(\Delta_{p})} f(S_i(x)) \nu_{p}(dx), \ \text{ as } \ l \to \infty. \end{aligned}$$ ◻
*Remark 14*. The existence and continuity of the branches of the inverse $R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }$ on the interval $[0,2]$ is given in a forthcoming work , where we develop a general framework by extending the results obtained in this paper to a large class of Jacobi operators.
Theorem 13 and proposition 12 justify the following definitions.
**Definition 15**. We refer to $\nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ and $\nu_p$ as the *density of states* of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ and $\Delta_{p}$, respectively. The corresponding are given by $N_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0}(x)=\nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0}((-\infty,x])$ and $N_{p}(x)=\nu_{p}((-\infty,x])$.
It now follows that
**Corollary 16**. *Let $E \subset \sigma(\Delta_{p})$, then $\nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }(S_j(E)) = \frac{1}{3^n} \nu_{p}(E)$.*
*Proof.* We compute $$\begin{aligned} \nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }(S_j(E)) =\frac{1 }{3^{n} } \sum_{i=1}^{3^n} \int_{\sigma(\Delta_{p})} \chi_{S_j(E)}(S_i(x)) \nu_{p}(dx) =\frac{1 }{3^{n} } \int_{\sigma(\Delta_{p})} \chi_{E}(x) \nu_{p}(dx), \end{aligned}$$ where in the second equality, we use that $\chi_{S_j(E)}(S_i(x)) = 0$ ($\nu_p$ almost surely), whenever $i \neq j$ and $\chi_{S_j(E)}(S_j(x)) = \chi_{E}(x)$. ◻
The intuitively, Theorem 13 implies that the density of states $\nu_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ equally distributes the original mass $\nu_{p}$ of the spectrum $\sigma(\Delta_{p})$ on the $3^n$ branches of the inverse spectral decimation function $R^{-1}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }$. In particular, this enables us to compute the spectral gap labels of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$. Let $\rho(\Delta_{p})$ be the resolvent set of $\Delta_{p}$. We define the set of spectral gap labels of $\Delta_{p}$ by $$\begin{aligned} \mathscr{G} \mathscr{L}(\Delta_{p}) = \{ N_p(x) \ | \ x \in \rho(\Delta_{p}) \cap \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{R}}}\}. \end{aligned}$$ It is not difficult to see that $\mathscr{G} \mathscr{L}(\Delta_{\frac{1}{2}}) =\{0,1\}$. For $p \neq \frac{1}{2}$, we have $$\begin{aligned} \mathscr{G} \mathscr{L}(\Delta_{p}) = \Big\{ \frac{j}{3^i} \ \Big| \ i \in \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{N}}}, \ j \in \{0,1,\dots,3^i\} \Big\}. \end{aligned}$$ We define the set of spectral gap labels of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ similarly and denote it by $\mathscr{G} \mathscr{L}(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 })$.
**Corollary 17** (Gap labeling). *The set of spectral gap labels of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ is given by $$\begin{aligned} \mathscr{G} \mathscr{L}(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }) \subset \Big\{ \frac{j}{3^n}+ \frac{1}{3^n}\mathscr{G} \mathscr{L}(\Delta_{p}) \ \Big| \ \ j \in \{0,1,\dots,3^n-1\} \Big\}. \end{aligned}$$*
# Examples and numerical results ## Spectra of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(1)}$ and $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(2)}$ We apply the above framework for finite graphs in the case $p=\frac{1}{3}$, $\beta=1$ and $\alpha = \frac{1}{3}$. Direct computations give $\sigma(\Delta^{(0)})=\{0,2\}$. With Proposition 10 we compute the exceptional set and $R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0}$, $$\label{eq:spectralDecimationfunctionAndExceptset} \mathscr{E}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 } = \left\{ - \frac{1}{6} , \ - \frac{5}{6} \right\}, \quad \quad R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(z)= \frac{9 z^{3}}{2} - \frac{55 z}{8} - \frac{9}{8}.$$ We give an illustration of Theorem 4. Due to the spectral similarity between $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(1)}$ and $\Delta^{(0)}$, we see that $z\in\sigma(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(1)})\setminus\mathscr{E}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }$ if and only if $R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(z)\in\sigma(\Delta^{(0)})$. We compute the preimage sets $R^{-1}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(0)$ and $R^{-1}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(2)$, see Figure [fig:firstOffsprings] and Table [1](#tab:table1). We note that $R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }$ is a polynomial of degree 3; therefore, each of the eigenvalues $0, 2 \in \sigma(\Delta^{(0)})$ generates three preimages. Excluding the exceptional points results in four distinct eigenvalues of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(1)}$, which on the other hand, determine the complete spectrum as $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(1)}$ is a $4\times4$ matrix. To compute $\sigma(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(2)})$, we first use Proposition 6 and the spectral decimation function $R_{\Delta_{p}}$ to calculate $\sigma(\Delta^{(1)}_{p})$. It can be easily checked that $\sigma(\Delta^{(1)}_{p})=\{0,\frac{1}{3},\frac{5}{3},2\}$. In particular, four out of the ten eigenvalues in $\sigma( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(2)})$ are computed similarly to above, namely as the elements of preimage sets $R^{-1}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(0)$ and $R^{-1}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(2)$ with excluding the points in the exceptional set. The preimage sets $R^{-1}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(1/3)$ and $R^{-1}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(5/3)$ are computed as shown in Figure [fig:SecondOffsprings] with the numerical values in Table [2](#tab: spectraForAlpha1over3first3levelsh2). These sets generate the remaining 6 eigenvalues. Note in level two, the graph $G_2$ consists of $10$ vertices. ## Spectral gaps The disconnectedness of the Julia set $\mathcal{J}(R_{\Delta_{p}})$, for $p \neq \frac{1}{2}$, implies that the self-similar Laplacian $\Delta_{p}$ has infinitely many spectral gaps. This fact combined with Theorem 11 lead us to the following two conclusions: 1. For $p \neq \frac{1}{2}$, the spectrum $\sigma \Big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 } \Big)$ has infinitely many spectral gaps. 2. We can generate the spectral gaps iteratively using the spectral decimation function $R_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n},0 }$. We illustrate these ideas with the example $p=\frac{1}{3}$, $\beta=1$, $\alpha = \frac{1}{3}$, $\theta=0$ and generate the spectral gaps in $\sigma \big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 } \big)$ using $$R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(z)= \frac{9 z^{3}}{2} - \frac{55 z}{8} - \frac{9}{8}.$$ To locate the first two spectral gaps of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }$, we note that $\sigma(\Delta_{\frac{1}{3}}) \subset [0,2]$. By Theorem 11, we obtain $$\begin{aligned} z \in \sigma \Big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 } \Big) \quad \Rightarrow \quad R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(z) \in [0,2], \end{aligned}$$ or equivalently $$\begin{aligned} R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(z) \notin [0,2] \quad \Rightarrow \quad z \in \rho \Big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 } \Big). \end{aligned}$$ Plotting the spectral decimation function $R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }$ with both cutoffs $y=0$ and $y=2$ in Figure [fig:GeneratinggapsAMOfirstTwoGaps], generates the first two spectral gaps $gap_1$ and $gap_2$. By Proposition 9, we know that $z \in \sigma \big(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(1)}\big) \bigcup \sigma \big(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(1),D} \big)$ if and only if $R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3},0}(z) \in \{0,2\}$. The eigenvalues of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(1)}$ are listed in Table [1](#tab:table1) and we denote the eigenvalues $\sigma \big(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }^{(1),D} \big) = \{-\frac{5}{6}, -\frac{1}{6} \}$ by $\lambda^{(1),D}_1 =-\frac{5}{6}$ and $\lambda^{(1),D}_2 = -\frac{1}{6}$. This gives $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:orderingEigenvalues} \lambda^{(1)}_1 \leq \lambda^{(1),D}_1 \leq \lambda^{(1)}_2 \leq \lambda^{(1),D}_2 \leq \lambda^{(1)}_3 \leq \lambda^{(1)}_4. \end{aligned}$$ The spectrum of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }$ is then contained in the complement (in $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{R}}}$) of the following set $$\begin{aligned} (-\infty, \lambda^{(1)}_1) \cup (\lambda^{(1),D}_1, \lambda^{(1)}_2) \cup (\lambda^{(1),D}_2, \lambda^{(1)}_3) \cup (\lambda^{(1)}_4,\infty), \end{aligned}$$ where $gap_1=(\lambda^{(1),D}_1, \lambda^{(1)}_2)$ and $gap_2 = (\lambda^{(1),D}_2, \lambda^{(1)}_3)$. To generate the next spectral gaps, we proceed similarly and note that $$\sigma(\Delta_{\frac{1}{3}}) \subset \big[0,\frac{1}{3}\big] \cup \big[\frac{2}{3}, \frac{4}{3}\big] \cup \big[\frac{5}{3}, 2\big]$$ where $\sigma(\Delta^{(1)}_{p})=\{0,\frac{1}{3},\frac{5}{3},2\}$ and $\sigma(\Delta^{(1),D}_{p})=\{\frac{2}{3},\frac{4}{3}\}$ (with Dirichlet boundary conditions). Hence, $$\begin{aligned} R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }(z) \in \Big( \frac{1}{3},\frac{2}{3} \Big) \cup \Big( \frac{4}{3},\frac{5}{3} \Big) \quad \Rightarrow \quad z \in \rho \Big( \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 } \Big). \end{aligned}$$ Plotting the spectral decimation function $R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{3}, 0 }$ with both cutoffs $y=\frac{1}{3}$, $\frac{2}{3}$ and $y=\frac{4}{3}$, $y=\frac{5}{3}$ in Figure [fig:GeneratinggapsAMOnext6Gaps], generates the next six spectral gaps. ## Gap labeling Figures [fig:IDSAMOalpha1over9p1over2] and [fig:IDSAMOalpha1over9p1over3] give a numerical illustration of [eq:almostSelfSimiId]). We recall that the spectral decimation function $R_{\frac{1}{2},1, \frac{1}{9},0 }$ is a polynomial of degree $9$. As such, Figure [fig:IDSAMOalpha1over9p1over2] shows that on each range of the nine branches $S_i(\Delta_{\frac{1}{2}})$, we have a copy of Figure [fig:IDSforLaps] (left) rescaled by $\frac{1}{9}$, according to Corollary 16. This case corresponds to a periodic Jacobi matrix, and the spectrum consists of nine spectral bands. As expected from Corollary 17, the set of spectral gap labels is $$\begin{aligned} \mathscr{G} \mathscr{L}(\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{\frac{1}{2},1, \frac{1}{9}, 0 }) = \Big\{ 0, \frac{1}{9}, \frac{2}{9}, \dots , 1 \Big\}. \end{aligned}$$ Similarly, the spectral decimation function $R_{\frac{1}{3},1, \frac{1}{9},0 }$ is a polynomial of degree $9$. As such, Figure [fig:IDSAMOalpha1over9p1over3] shows that on each range of the nine branches $S_i(\Delta_{\frac{1}{3}})$, we have a copy of Figure [fig:IDSforLaps] (right) rescaled by $\frac{1}{9}$. In particular, this highlight the Cantor set structure inherited from $\sigma(\Delta_{\frac{1}{3}})$ and the set of spectral gap labels is deduced from Corollary 17. # Connections approaches of Béllissard and Bessis-Geronimo-Moussa Our work is partially motivated by Bellissard’s studies on Hamiltonians describing the motion of a particle in quasicrystals. More specifically, his construction of a large class of Hamiltonians with Cantor spectra starting from Jacobi matrices and their associated Julia sets, see . To draw the parallel with our work we make the following observations. Given a polynomial $P(z)$, let $\mathcal{J}(P)$ be the corresponding (compact) Julia set, which, under some assumptions on $P(z)$ is a completely disconnected set . In addition, let $\mu$ be the balanced invariant measure of $\mathcal{J}(P)$ and consider the Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}=L^2(\mathcal{J}(R), d\mu)$. The multiplication operator $H$ associated with the identity function $f(x)=x$ in $\mathcal{H}$ is bounded, self adjoint, has the Cantor set $\mathcal{J}(P)$ as spectrum. Furthermore, $\mu$ is the spectral measure of $H$ leading to a singular spectrum. Because the linearly independent set $\{x \in \mathcal{J}(P) \to x^n \in \mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{C}}}\}$ generates a dense linear subspace of $\mathcal{H}$, the operator $H$ can be represented as a semi-infinite Jacobi matrix. Moreover, $H$ satisfies a *renormalization group equation* $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:RenoGroBelli} D \big( zI-H \big)^{-1} D^{\ast} =\frac{P'(z)}{deg(P)} \big( P(z)I-H \big)^{-1} \end{aligned}$$ where the partial isometry $D$ and its adjoint $D^{\ast}$ are given in . The connection between our work and Bellissard’s original ideas as elaborated above begins by using defining a probabilistic Laplacian (the so-called *pq-model*) on the integers half-line $\mathbb{Z}_+$, regarded as a hierarchical or substitution graph with $G_1$ in Figure [fig:G1_initialNeumann] (right) as its basic building block. The graph $G_1$ determines the spectral decimation function $R_{\Delta_{p}}(z)$ in [eq:specDeciFuncLap], a polynomial which plays the role of the polynomial $P(z)$ appearing in Bellissard’s approach. On the one hand, each Laplacian $\Delta_p$ represents an example of a semi-infinite Jacobi matrix that, in similarly to the operators in Bellissard’s construction, has a spectrum that coincides with $\mathcal{J}(R_{\Delta_{p}})$: the Julia set of the polynomial $R_{\Delta_{p}}(z)$. On the other hand, the balance measure of $\mathcal{J}(R_{\Delta_{p}})$ plays the role of the spectral measure in Bellissard’s approach and is also the density of states in our context, see Proposition 12. In a forthcoming work , we generalize the substitution rule in Definition 2 leading to a multiple-parameter families of probabilistic Laplacians whose spectral properties are investigated with similar tools as the aforementioned *pq-model*. We note that the spectra of the self-similar almost Mathieu operators we introduced in this paper are not necessarily given as the Julia sets of some polynomials. Instead, as proved in Theorem 11 these spectra are preimages of Julia sets under certain polynomials. In , these results are extended to a class of Jacobi operators, for which we establish a renormalization group equation, see . For example, when reduced to the *pq-model*, this renormalization group equation for resolvent, see , takes the form $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:RenoGrEqOURapproach} U^{\ast}\big(z I- \Delta_{p} \big)^{-1}U=\frac{(z-1)^2-p^2}{p(1-p)}\Big( R_{\Delta_{p}}(z) I - \Delta_{p} \Big)^{-1}, \end{aligned}$$ where $R_{\Delta_{p}}(z)$ is given in [eq:specDeciFuncLap], and $U$ and $U^{\ast}$ are defined in . For comparison with [eq:RenoGroBelli], we compute $$\begin{aligned} \frac{\frac{d}{dz}R_{\Delta_{p}}(z) }{deg(R_{\Delta_{p}})} = \frac{(z-1)^2-\big(\frac{1-p(1-p)}{3}\big)}{p(1-p)}, \end{aligned}$$ which coincides with the factor on the right-hand side of equation ([eq:RenoGrEqOURapproach]) if and only if $p=\frac{1}{2}$. Thus, our results is related to , although we do not rely on as we consider a model which allows us to produce more explicit computation of the spectrum for operators with potential. # Conclusions In this paper we introduce and study a fractal version of the almost Mathieu operators $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \alpha, \theta }$. We propose a new adaptation of the method of spectral similarity to analyze their spectral properties. Our main conclusions are the following. 1. Theorem 11 presents a useful algebraic tool to relate the spectrum of the almost Mathieu operators $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \alpha, \theta }$ to that of a family of self-similar Laplacians $\Delta_p$. Our results are established when the parameter $\alpha$ belongs to the dense set $\{\tfrac{k}{3^n}, \, k=0,1, 2, \hdots, 3^n-1\}_{n=1}^l$ where $l\geq 1$. Note that in the classical case, corresponding to $p=1/2$ in our formulation, many important results are also obtained for $\alpha$ irrational, but in the fractal setting the methods for irrational $\alpha$ are not developed yet. The method of spectral similarity is applicable in many situations, and in a forthcoming work we develop a general framework by working with a large class of Jacobi operators. We call these operators piecewise centrosymmetric Jacobi operators . In this general setting the spectral decimation function can be computed using the theory of orthogonal polynomials associated with the aforementioned Jacobi matrix. As a result, the spectral decimation function in the generalizations of Theorem 4 can be computed using a three-term recurrence relation, which provides a simple procedure to show that the spectral decimation function is a polynomial of a specific degree with properties that can be controlled. 2. Our methods allow to compute explicitly the density of states. In particular, we proved in theorem 13 an explicit formula connecting the density of states of $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ by identifying it with the weighted preimages of the balanced invariant measure on the Julia set of the polynomial $\mathcal{J}(R_{\Delta_{p}})$. This approach can be generalized to many other situations, and can be verified numerically, see Section 5. 3. In our particular situation we are able to conclude that the operators $\mathop{\mathrm{\mathbb{{\textbf{H}}}}}_{p,\beta, \frac{k}{3^n}, 0 }$ have singularly continuous spectrum when $p\neq \frac{1}{2}$ because of the previous recent work that the spectrum is singularly continuous for $\Delta_p$. This result requires a detailed analysis of a certain dynamical system describing the behavior of the generalized eigenfunction. 4. A particular novelty of our results is that we develop the spectral analysis of a self-similar Laplacian with a quasi-periodic potential. In our work we have made the essential steps towards the Fourier analysis on one-dimensional self-similar structures following the general approach developed by Strichartz et al . In certain particular situations this allows to consider classical and quantum wave prorogation on fractal and other irregular structures . 5. Using these Harmonic Analysis tools, our work introduces a direct approach to the gap labeling for a self-similar Laplacian with a potential. In particular, this direct approach for gap labeling is complementing . In our case we do not make use of the dual of a group acting on the fractal lattice, and observe that gap labels of the form $\frac{j}{3^n}$ are consistent with the self-similar quasi-periodic structure where renormalization acts by the dilation of the space by $3^n$. This should be contrasted with the gap labeling for fractal structures with more complicated topological structure currently under investigation in , including the classical Sierpinski gasket and a new model of the bubble diamond fractals. In general, on a certain class of self-similar structures the gaps are labeled by the values of the integrated density of states of the Laplacian with values $\frac{j}{C^n}$ where $C$ is the topological degree of the self-covering map of the fractal limit space. Thus, our work sets the stage for considering the Bloch theorem, noncommutative Chern characters and fractal-based quantum Hall systems, see , as well as . On fractal spaces this is an open problem that has not been previously considered in the literature besides the recent work . 6. Our work is connected to several lines of investigations in mathematics and physics, including the topics highlighted at the recent workshop [Quasi-periodic spectral and topological analysis](https://alexander-teplyaev.uconn.edu/quasi-periodic-spectral-and-topological-analysis/), and in particular the work of E. Akkermans , D. Damanik , S. Jitomirskaya , and E. Prodan et al. ## Acknowledgments The work of G.  Mograby was supported by ARO grant W911NF1910366.
